title-group.article-title: Novalis' "Hymnen an die Nacht" and the Prose Poem "avant la lettre"

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1983 The Trustees of Boston University

p.mixed-citation: Novalis, Schriften II, Gen eds., Paul Kluckhohn and Richard Samuel (Stuttgart: W: Kohl- hammer, 1960), 413/1.
Suzanne Bernard, Le Poeme en prose de Baudelaire jusqu'd nos jours (Paris: Nizet, 1958), pp. 24-47.
Barbara Herrnstein Smith, Poetic Closure (Chicago: U. of Chicago Press, 1968), p. 22.
E. D. Hirsch, Jr. Validity in Interpretation (New Haven: Yale U.'Press, 1967), pp. 94-98
Jonathan Culler's Structuralist Poetics (London: Routledge and Kegan Paul, 1975), pp. 161-64.

Bernard: . . . le vers libre nait d'un desir d'assouplir le vers classique et de le rapprocher des rhythmes libres de la prose . . . ("free verse is born of a desire to render classical verse more supple and to bring it closer to the rhythms of prose"), p. 592.
Jacques Derrida, White Mythology, trans. F. C. T. Moore, in New Literary History 6 (1974), 52, 68. Further reference is indicated in the text by W. M. followed by the page number.
Philippe Lacoue- Labarthe and Jean-Luc Nancy, in L'Absolu litteraire (Paris: Seuil, 1978), p. 193.
Paul Ricoeur's discussion of "semantic shock" in his The Rule of Metaphor, trans. Robert Czerny (Toronto: U. of Toronto Press, 1975), p. 296.
Novalis, of course, Christianity is the sum of all religions: Es giebt keine Religion die nicht Xstenthum ware ("There is no religion which would not be Christianity," F.S., 566/ 82).

"If Christ were to come again, he would be one with Mary"â€”Friedrich Schlegel, Literarische Notizen (1797-1801), Literary Notebooks, ed. Hans Eichner (Frankfurt: Ullstein, 1980), p. 221, fragment 2188. Hereafter referred to as L.N. followed by the page and fragment number.
